9목Single crystal crystallography. Crystallographical data of BPPOC was collected on a diffractometer of SuperNova, Dual, Cu at home/near, AtlasS2 with Cu K붸 radiation (뷂 = 1.54184 ?) at 150.00 K. The structure was solved by the direct method (SHELXS-2014) and refined by full-matrix least-squares (SHELXL-2014) on F2.S1a,S1b Anisotropic thermal parameters were used for the non-hydrogen atoms and isotropic parameters for the hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were added geometrically and refined using a riding model. Crystallographic and refinement parameters for organic cages are compiled in Table S1. Because there are seriously disordered solvent molecules in the cage pores, 몵SQUEEZE몶 command was employed. CCDC 2143974 for BPPOC contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.S5Iodine vapor uptake and recycling  experiments . Time-dependent  iodine  vapor  uptake  experiments  were  performed  using  the following  procedure:  The POCs  and COFs  samples  (10.0  mg) were  weighed  in a preweighed  glass  vessel  (5 mL) and then transferred  to a larger  sealed  glass  vial (50 mL) containing  800.0  mg iodine  at the bottom.  There  was not physical  contact  between  the iodine  and the samples.  Next,  the closed  container  was heated  at 75 뫢C in an oven.  After  iodine  vapor  adsorption,  the iodine-loaded  materials  were  cooled  to room  temperature  and weighed.  The iodine  uptake  capacities  were  calculated  using  the weight  gain:  C = (W a ? Wb)/W b g g?1, where  C is the iodine  uptake  capacity,  and Wa and Wb are the weight  of the materials  after  and before  iodine  vapor  adsorption,  respectively.  For adsorbent  recycling,  a portion  of iodine-equilibrium  powder  was heated  at 125 뫢C under  vacuum  for 4.0 h, affording  a regenerated  material  for cycling.

1목뫴EXPERIMENTAL SECTIONGeneral Remarks. All reagents were commercially available andused directly. BTPOC, BTDDP, and 5-(4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)isophthalaldehyde were synthesized following apreviously published procedure.12Synthesis of 5,5 뫣-([2,2 뫣-Bipyridine]-5,5 뫣-diyl)-diisophthalaldehyde. A mixture of 5,5 뫣-dibromo-2,2 뫣-bipyridine(628.0 mg, 2.0 mmol), 5-(4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)isophthalaldehyde (1100.0 mg, 4.2 mmol), potassium carbonate(1000.0 mg, 7.2 mmol), tetrakis(tr iphenylphosphine)palladium(150.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), tetrahydrofuran (18.0 mL), and water (2.0mL) in a 50 mL ?ask was stirred at 95 뫢C under a nitrogenatmosphere. After 24 h, the reaction mixture was cooled to roomtemperature and ?ltered. The crude product was washed with eachwater (10.0 mL), tetrahydrofuran (10.0 mL), and methanol (10.0mL) and ?nally dried at room temperature, a ?ording BPDDP ( ca. 700mg) with a yield of 83%. BPDDP possesses the solubility of less than10.0 mg/cm3in DMSO- d6.1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO- d6):붻(ppm) 10.25 (s, 4H), 9.20 (s, 2H), 8.63 (d, 6H), 8.46 (d, 4H);13CNMR (100 MHz, DMSO- d6):붻(ppm) 193.04, 148.30, 138.07,136.32, 134.24, 133.72, 129.57, 121.33.

2목Synthesis of BPPOC. To a suspension of BPDDP (210.2 mg, 0.5mmol) and TFA (5.0 뷃L) in dichloromethane (450.0 mL), a solutionof chiral R,R-cyclohexanediamine (125.6 mg, 1.1 mmol) in dichloro-methane (50.0 mL) was added slowly and stirred at roomtemperature. After 48 h, the reaction mixture was ?ltered. The ?ltratewas then evaporated under reduced pressure. Recrystallization of thecrude product in dichloromethane and methanol led to theprecipitation of the target organic cage as a light yellow powder,which was dried at room temperature, giving BPPOC in the yield of81% (209 mg).

4목Synthesis of USTB-1, USTB-2, and USTB-3. A Pyrex tube (9.0뫄6.0 mm, o.d. 뫄i.d.) was ?lled with BPDDP (12.6 mg, 0.03 mmol),diamine (BZ for USTB-1 and BPDA for USTB-2, 0.06 mmol), o-DCB(0.9 mL), 1-butanol (0.1 mL), and 6 M aqueous acetic acid (0.1 mL).

5목After sonicating the tube for 15.0 min, followed by ?ash freezing in aliquid N2bath, the frozen tube was degassed and slowly warmed toroom temperature. After repeating such a process three times, thetube was sealed. The reaction was performed at 120 뫢C for 3 days,generating yellow precipitates. The solids were isolated by ?ltrationand successively washed with o-DCB and acetone three times. Theproducts were collected and dried at 100 뫢C under vacuum overnight,providing the yellow powder of USTB-1 (15.6 mg) and USTB-2 (15.9mg), respectively. FT-IR (KBr) for USTB-1: 1622, 1591, 1485, 1135,958, 835, 743 cm?1. FT-IR (KBr) for USTB-2: 1621, 1590, 1458,1141, 1017, 967, 835, 737 cm?1.
6목USTB-3 was prepared as a yellow powder (16.4 mg) using thesynthetic protocol for preparing USTB-1 with BTDDP (13.0 mg, 0.03mmol) instead of BPDDP as the starting material for 5 days 몶reaction.

8목Cage-to-COF Transformation. The solvothermal reaction ofBPPOC (17.3 mg, 0.01 mmol) with BZ/BPDA (0.06 mmol) wascarried out in the solvent mixture of o-DCB (0.9 mL), 1-butanol (0.1mL), and 6 M aqueous acetic acid (0.1 mL) for 3 days. The solidproducts were isolated through ?ltration, successively washing with o-DCB and acetone three times, and drying at 100 뫢C, giving yellowpowders of USTB-1c (17.8 mg) and USTB-2c (17.0 mg),respectively. FT-IR (KBr) for USTB-1c: 1622, 1597, 1487, 1146,967, 831, 739 cm?1. FT-IR (KBr) for USTB-2c: 1623, 1591, 1460,1148, 1019, 970, 836, 739 cm?1.

9목USTB-3c and USTB-4c were prepared by employing the sameprocedure used for preparing USTB-1c with BTPOC (17.6 mg, 0.01mmol) instead of BPPOC (17.3 mg, 0.01 mmol) as the startingmaterial in o-DCB (0.7 mL) and 1-butanol (0.3 mL), a ?ordingUSTB-3c (18.2 mg) and USTB-4c (17.9 mg) as yellow powders. FT-IR (KBr) for USTB-3c: 1621, 1589, 1485, 1140, 1001, 964, 831, 740cm?1. FT-IR (KBr) for USTB-4c: 1621, 1592, 1459, 1278, 1143, 969,832, 740 cm?1.뫴ASSOCIATED CONTENT*s?Supporting InformationThe Supporting Information is available free of charge athttps://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/jacs.2c03959 .

5목Synthesis of 1,1',1'',1'''-([2,2'-bithiophene]-4,4'-diylbis(benzene-5,1,3-triyl))tetrakis(N-cyclohexylmethanimine) (BDTC). A mixture of BTDDP (215.3 mg, 0.5 mmol), cyclohexylamine (218.2 mg, 2.2 mmol), trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) (5.0 뷃L), and chloroform (125.0 mL) in a 250 mL flask was stirred at 55 oC. After 24 hours, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure. Recrystallization of solid in dichloromethane and methanol led to the precipitation of white microcrystal, which was dried at room temperature, giving BDTC in the yield of 62% (235.2 mg). It is worth noting that BTDDP is insoluble in dichloromethane, chloroform, tetrahydrofuran, toluene, and only sparingly soluble in DMSO. After reacting of BTDDP and cyclohexylamine, the solubility of BDTC in organic solvents is greatly improved. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6): 붻 (ppm) 8.40 (s, 4H), 8.03 (d, 4H), 7.96 (d, 2H), 7.59 (d, 2H), 7.47 (d, S32H), 3.24 (tt, 4H), 1.90-1.59 (m, 28H), 1.49-1.23 (m, 12H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, DMSO-d 6) 붻 (ppm) 158.06, 141.94, 137.96, 137.61, 136.19, 127.32, 127.20, 123.23, 120.34, 70.08, 34.39, 25.67, 24.86.

6목Synthesis of USTB-4'. USTB-4' were prepared by employing the same procedure for preparing USTB-1c with BDTC (44.3 mg, 0.06 mmol) and BPDA (22.3 mg, 0.12 mmol) as starting material in o-DCB (0.7 mL), 1-butanol (0.3 mL), and 6 M aqueous acetic acid (0.1 mL), affording USTB-4' (33.1 mg) as yellow powder.

11목BPPOC displays very low N 2uptake at even 1.0 bar, giving alow Brunauer ?Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 52 m2g?1,Figure S23 . Instead, on the basis of CO 2adsorption data at196 K, Figure S24 , the BET surface area of BPPOC is 577 m2g?1, similar to that of BTPOC (605 m2g?1) under the sametest conditions.12Activated USTB-1 and USTB-2 degassed at100 뫢C show a type-I gas sorption curve at 77 K, Figure 3 ,indicating the microporous characteristics of these twomaterials. The BET surface areas were calculated to be 1322m2g?1for USTB-1 and 322 m2g?1for USTB-2. The pore sizedistribution study reveals the dual-pore structure with the sizeof 1.88 and 2.18 nm for USTB-1 and 1.89 and 2.15 nm forUSTB-2, Figure 3 a?d. The values for both materials are quiteclose to the theoretical pore sizes of 1.84 and 2.02 nm,con?rming their same Kagome lattice nature.

12목14The total porevolumes were calculated as 0.66 and 0.22 cm3g?1for USTB-1and USTB-2, respectively. For USTB-3, Figure 3 e, the verysmall BET surface area of 20 m2g?1might also be due to itspoor crystalline state, preventing us from ?tting the pore sizedistribution. As for the cage-derived COFs ranging fromUSTB-1c to USTB-4c, their BET surface areas weresigni?cantly enhanced to 1454, 365, 598, and 441 m2g?1,respectively. The pore sizes of USTB-1c and USTB-2c areoverall consistent with the theoretical values deduced from thepredesigned COF structures, Figure 3 b,d. This is also true forUSTB-3c (1.71 and 2.08 nm) and USTB-4c (1.81 and 2.04nm), Figure 3 f,h. At the end of this paragraph, it is noteworthythat the BET surface area of 193 m2g?1for USTB-4 뫣is smallerthan that of USTB-4c (441 m2g?1),Figure S25 , con?rming thein?uence of di ?erent starting materials on the preparation ofhigh-quality COFs.

14목15?21A variety of adsorbents including MOFs,15COFs,16?18and POCs12,19?21have been disclosed to exhibithigh-e ?ciency iodine capture performance in comparison withcommercial zeolites and active carbons. In the present case, theisolated POCs and 2D COFs possessing well-de ?ned porousstructures in combination with their heteroatom-rich molecularmodule nature most probably endow them with good I2capture properties by forming charge-transfer species.12,18Asa consequence, the iodine vapor capture experiments wereperformed on two POCs and seven COFs at 348 K. BPPOCdisplays the iodine adsorption amount of 5.34 g g?1after 20 hand gets saturated with 5.64 g g?1after 50 h, Figure 4 a,b. Theiodine vapor adsorption capability of this cage is better thanthe POC benchmarks including OMC319(3.78 g g?1), BPy-Cage20(3.23 g g?1), and CC321(0.45 g g?1). However, thesulfur-rich cage BTPOC shows a much lower iodine vaporadsorption uptake of 3.21 g g?1than the nitrogen-richcounterpart BPPOC despite their similar BET surfaceareas,12revealing the nitrogen-rich superiority in iodinecapture. Actually, such a high iodine vapor adsorption behaviorof BPPOC surpasses the excellent organic adsorbates such asmolecular crystals,22conjugated microporous polymers,23andporous aromatic frameworks,24Figure 4 c and Table S4 .USTB-1 exhibits a moderately high iodine vapor captureuptake of 4.45 g g?1. The other two directly prepared dual-poreCOFs, USTB-2 and USTB-3, show slightly lower iodine vaporcapacities with the uptake of 4.38 and 3.14 g g?1, respectively,Figure 4 a. Their di ?erence in iodine vapor capacities might beattributed to the synergy e ?ect between the heteroatomcomponent and experimental pore volumes. Interestingly,cage-derived USTB-1c was revealed to display an enhancediodine vapor capacity of 5.80 g g?1in comparison with that ofUSTB-1 (4.45 g g?1). This is indeed also true for the increasediodine uptake of 4.57 and 3.30 g g?1for USTB-2c and USTB-3c, respectively, compared wi th their directly preparedcounterparts, due probably to the formation of more porositybetween cage-derived COF crystallites than the directlyprepared species according to the higher experimental N2uptake at 1 bar revealed by the adsorption curves. USTB-4cpossesses a moderate iodine adsorption amount of 3.02 g g?1.

1목In the present case, the nitrogen-rich COFs, USTB-1 (1c) andUSTB-2 (2c), seem to exhibit higher iodine vapor uptakes thanthe corresponding sulfur-rich species USTB-3 (3c) and USTB-4c, respectively, under the same conditions. This is actuallyconsistent with the phenomena observed for POCs asmentioned above. However, it is noteworthy that both thenitrogen-rich structure nature and high surface area (porosity)play an important role in the I2vapor uptake of COFs.

2목Nevertheless, additional sites such as interlayers also contributeto I2capture of COFs, as indicated by the larger absorbed I2volume (0.90 and 1.18 cm3g?1) than the experimental porevolume (0.66 and 1.01 cm3g?1) of USTB-1 and USTB-1c,respectively. This then should be responsible for the similar I2adsorption uptakes for USTB-3 and USTB-3c possessing verydi?erent BET surface areas.

10목Herein, a new single-crystal [3 + 6] topological POC(BPPOC) was obtained from the condensation between 3equiv 2,2 뫣-bipyridine-based tetraaldehyde (BPDDP) moleculesand 6 equiv R,R-cyclohexanediamine molecules, catalyzed bytri?uoroacetic acid. The replacement of R,R-cyclohexanedi-amine by rod-like diamine molecules including benzidine (BZ)and [2,2 뫣-bipyridine]-5,5 뫣-diamine (BPDA) to assemble withBPDDP a ?ords isostructural 2D COFs under solvothermalconditions, which are denoted as USTB-1 and USTB-2 (USTB= University of Science and Technology Beijing), respectively.

13목뫴RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONDesign and Synthesis of POCs and COFs. [3 + 6] POCspioneered by Cooper bring a useful source code for thepreparation of new functional organic cages.13In the presentcase, a new functional POC, BPPOC, was designed andconstructed by incorporating bipyridine tetraaldehyde withcyclohexanediamine ( Scheme 1 . The tetraaldehyde buildingblock, BPDDP, was synthesized by the coupling reactionbetween 5,5 뫣-dibromo-2,2 뫣-bipyridine and 5-(4,4,5,5-tetra-methyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)isophthalaldehyde ( Figures S1and S2 ). BPDDP then reacted with cyclohexanediamine,yielding the target POC, BPPOC, which has good solubility incommon organic solvents like tetrahydrofuran, dichloro-Scheme 1. Synthesis and Structures of POCs and COFs as Well as Intersecting TransformationJournal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.org/JACS Articlehttps://doi.org/10.1021/jacs.2c03959J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2022, 144, 12390 ?1239912391methane, chloroform, and toluene. A series of1H NMR,1H?1H COSY,13C NMR, and electrospray ionization-massspectrometry (ESI MS) characterizations disclose thesuccessful generation of the conceived [3 + 6] POC ( FiguresS3?S6). In addition, this nitrogen-rich BPPOC shows highthermal stability above 360 뫢C according to the thermogravi-metric analysis ( Figure S7 ). In order to unveil the heteroatom-rich structure superiority in functions, a reported POC,BTPOC, made up of thiophene-containing BTDDP andcyclohexanediamine was also prepared as a reference.
